certain that whatever it may prove to be, it is <u>not</u>  an Orbitolite. So
again, the O.<u>lenticulata</u> of Lamarck, judging by the figure given
of it by Lamouroux (Polypieis Pl. lxxii Figs. 13.16), is <u>not</u> an
Orbitolite, but probably a Lunulite. Of the species subsequently
described by other authors, I entertain no doubts that the
<u>O. disculus</u> of M. Leymerie<sup>x</sup>, as well as in all probability the
<u>O. plana</u> of M. D'Archiac, is nothing else than <s>the</s> a variety of O. complanata;
more especially as its young is said to be like the <u>O. macropora</u> of
Maestricht. The <u>O. gensacica</u>, <u>O. secans</u>, and <u>O socialis</u> of
M. Leymerie, are all undoubtedly <u>Orbitolites</u>; and all
belong I believe, to the same species, though on this point
I could not speak positively, without an examination of
their internal structure. So, again, the <u>O. mamillata</u>, <u>O.
Fortisii</u> (O. gigantea of D'Orbigny) <u>O papyracea</u>, <u>O. stellata</u>,
<u>O. sella</u> and <u>O. radians</u> (O. radiata of D'Orbigny.) of M
D'Archiac<sup>+</sup> are <s>undoubted</s> all probably Orbitoides, as he himself
<u>subsequently recognised in regard at least to some of them<sup>‡</sup> </u>
x  Mem. Geol. Soc. of France, 2 ieme Ser Tom IV pp 190 191
+  D.  Tom ii p. 170 and 2 ieme Ser, Tom iii p.4
‡  Description des Animaux Fossiles du groupe Nummulitique
de l'Inde p. 350
